awd_titl_txt: RCN:MSB:FRA: Grassroots global network science: a macrosystems model
awd_abstract_narration:
Freshwater lakes and rivers sustain human economies, food supplies, and environmental and human health. In fact, modern societies are global networks of goods and services that are entirely dependent on freshwater.  Rapid global changes threaten many freshwater ecosystems across the globe, and the human networks that depend on them. Given the 100+ million lakes across the globe, very little is known about the role of lakes in regional-to-continental and even global-scale landscape function. The limited understanding comes from in-depth study of a handful of lakes, and it is assumed these represent the whole. What is needed is an expansion of studies to regions, continents, and ultimately the globe and to put that knowledge in the system contexts in which lakes sit - their atmospheric and surrounding land systems. Diverse perspectives, tools, and networks must be brought together to understand how global influences affect local water quality, the role of freshwater lakes in landscapes, and whether there are scaling rules (space and time) for generating regional- to continental- to cross-continental models for understanding how lake function. This need is far too vast to be the exclusive purview of any existing academic, research, federal, or private-sector network.  This project will build a global network of networks that includes scientists, as well as citizen scientists, to understand lake function over a variety of spatial and temporal scales and with different intensities of human-induced change.  

The overarching goal of this research is to use lessons, data, and physical and human infrastructure developed within the Global Lake Ecological Observatory Network to build an inclusive global network of networks capable of synthesizing information about lakes in the context of their connections to and feedbacks from the atmospheric, terrestrial, and human landscapes in which they sit. The assembly of resources, including human, data, and technical, will work in concert with the global network as a Research Coordination Network in the service of diverse teams of scientists who can take on big macrosystem science questions with effectiveness and persistence. Specifically, the proposed work will (i) develop a network capacity for incorporating and studying the interactions of atmosphere-terrestrial-aquatic systems by expanding their resource availability, human expertise, and connection to existing research programs; (ii) build on an existing, successful, learning organization that can accommodate new disciplines and needs; and (iii) use the enhanced/expanded network to provide a new capacity for doing the science of - and scientific training essential for - macrosystems biology about lakes embedded in atmosphere-terrestrial-human landscapes. Cross cutting scientific themes include exploration of feedbacks among and drivers in atmospheric-terrestrial-lake ecosystems, controls on material flow, and scaling from ecosystems to macrosystems.  Early career scientists will be encouraged to lead expeditions, with later career scientists as co-leaders. Based on past experience, this model builds the team for team science, leads to a major expansion of collaborative networks for participants, especially for early career scientists, and results in innovative interdisciplinary products. This award is cofunded by the Office of International Science and Engineering and includes collaborations with scientists in Australia, New Zealand, Ireland, Netherlands, Switzerland, Estonia, Taiwan, China, and Argentina.

por.por_cntn:
Freshwater ecosystems sustain human economies, food supplies, and environmental and human health. Modern societies are global networks of goods and services that are entirely dependent on freshwater.  Rapid global changes threaten many freshwater ecosystems across the globe, and the humans that depend on them. The 100+ million lakes on the planet are crucially important components of global freshwaters, even though they cover only a few percent of the land surface. Despite the prevalence of lakes across the globe, we know very little about the role of lake ecosystems in regional-to-continental, and even global-scale landscape function, and instead tend to focus, in depth, on just a handful of lakes, and assume these represent the whole. This project leveraged the grassroots Global Lake Ecological Observatory Network (GLEON), and its groundbreaking models both for catalyzing global lake science and for training and empowering early career network leadership. Activities brought together diverse perspectives, tools, and knowledge networks to understand the role of freshwater lakes in landscapes with different intensities of anthropogenic change.  In addition, the project explored capacities and ways in which the human network of people can be catalyzed to conduct innovative and inclusive science.   

Over one thousand scientists participated in six (three in person and three virtual) dynamic, interactive GLEON All Hands’ meetings from 2018-2023. At these GLEON meetings, hundreds of participants gained valuable skills and experiences through hands-on training sessions ranging from learning best practices for collaboration, leadership, and communication, to developing and applying ecosystem models to understand change, to how to create and evaluate ecological forecasts. At each All Hands’ meeting, an average of thirty percent of the attendees were new, indicating a steady expansion of the GLEON network.  Further, one third of the attendees were graduate students.  All Hands’ meeting attendees hailed from an average of 23 countries at each of these gatherings.  Post meeting surveys confirmed that, whether early career or later career participants, All Hands’ meetings were considered to have been inspirational.  From 60-85% of respondents felt that the most valuable outcomes of the meetings were exchanging new ideas and initiating new collaborations.  Among other scientific discoveries resulting from GLEON collaborations were identification of the widespread deoxygenation of temperate lakes, an analysis of lakes at risk of chloride (salt) contamination, how changes in ice cover are affecting human populations and livelihoods, and an exploration of plastic debris in lakes and reservoirs around the globe.

In addition to All Hands’ meetings, approximately 30 graduate students comprising three cohorts from over 20 different institutions were trained in both team science and leadership, as well as in new analytical skills under a GLEON Fellows/Lake Expedition Program.  Colleagues with expertise in Bayesian statistics, computer science and machine learning, and remote sensing were engaged in these GLEON programs, thereby expanding the network as well as extending domains of expertise within GLEON.  One cohort created ecological forecasts for cyanobacterial blooms in a north temperate lake, another learned and applied machine learning to over 100,000 lakes in the US to understand patterns of change in lakes that are shrinking or growing over time, and the third combined high frequency hyperspectral (remote sensing), lake microbial, and productivity data to demonstrate the promise of next generation satellites in understanding freshwater lake function. As a result of the GLEON Fellowship experience, guidance for creating new training models was synthesized and published.  This model stressed the mostly unmet need for training in leadership, project management, and conflict resolution in addition to the more traditional analytical skills that are part of graduate education.

As part of GLEON All Hands’ meetings as well as with the GLEON/Fellows Lake Expedition program, engagement with local or indigenous communities has become regular.  These locally engaged activities have ranged from presentations for lake-oriented communities on cutting edge science, to holding training sessions with volunteer monitors and lake associations, to hosting presentations by indigenous partners during All Hands’ meetings.  

Through this project, innovative global lake science was catalyzed and new models for interdisciplinary training in network science were developed and put into action.  An analysis of how GLEON has moved the dial for ecosystem science of lakes, as well as for scientists and community members, is in progress. Preliminary results underscore that a disciplinary, geographically, culturally diverse network of practitioners who adopt best practices of team science are able to advance the science most creatively and effectively.
